Chapter 8: The Eighteen Distinctive Abilities of the Buddha
Furthermore, Jewel Girl!

When practicing the bodhisattva path, for all beings who are always lost, guide them on the path, level out the uneven, dangerous, high, and low paths, and set up bridges. In dark and remote places, establish lofty and vast Buddhist temples.

If there are people who are in doubt and sin, for the sake of innumerable beings, remove the sin of doubt and prevent them from falling into misfortune and having a place. Also, do not give rise to doubt in others.

Without speaking of others' faults or saying that someone has committed an offense, knowing the dispositions of countless beings, eliminating all beings' aspirations and practices, and expounding the Dharma without doubt or hesitation, one then causes the Dharma to flourish and shine, and bestows it with the illumination of great wisdom. Encouraging all Buddhas and Bodhisattvas to expound the scriptures, using the grace of the Dharma to give without flattery, creating good karma and transforming each other, never despising others or being frivolous, not being fickle, not harming others or disparaging them, not being arrogant about the practices in one's country, and only believing the Buddha's words.

Following the teachings of the written word and attaining mastery, knowing that the written word is empty, not seeing faults in the matters of all words, not seeking their shortcomings, not looking at their deficiencies.
If a Bodhisattva practices such a Dharma and attains Buddhahood, this is called being without faults.

Practicing the bodhisattva path, one abandons all evil speech, speaking with sincerity, taking the Dharma as the basis and taking reasoning as the main point, teaching and transforming as the occupation, not being false or harmful, and completely abandoning non-sage words. Like an illusion, without thought or conception, do not indulge in self-satisfaction. Have an equal mind towards all types of sentient beings, equally contemplate all dharmas within the single Dharma realm, and enter into the indestructible.

Practicing the bodhisattva path, without inverted thoughts or notions, the mind does not engage in counteraction, does not create wrong views, and does not engage in falsehood. One does not conceive of self, body, person, or life, nor does one have the notion of a life-force, the notion of a person, the notion of a human mind, the notion of a cut-off [existence], the notion of permanence, the notion of various views, the notion of the three realms, or the notion of being apart from the three realms.

There is neither good nor bad, neither blameworthy nor blameless, neither contaminated nor uncontaminated, neither worldly nor transcending the world. Excluding the roots of afflictions, there is neither birth and death nor the notion of nirvana, nor the notion of accepting gatherings.

The inclinations, dispositions, and thoughts of sentient beings are inverted. Having eliminated this, one cultivates various wholesome [activities]. Then, one is far removed from the notions of ordinary beings and abandons all kinds of wrong views. Also, in the middle, one does not rely on anything and observes the Dharma of equality.

When practicing the bodhisattva path, one's mind always observes those who wander in birth and death. One does not become anxious about seeking various benefits, and then removes the bonds of longing and admiration;

Contemplate that all myriad things are impermanent and subject to suffering!
Do not contemplate the Dharma of the body, but have faith in the quiescence of nirvana, and already contemplate the various people.
Thus, observe all dharmas with such forms and appearances, and practice and cultivate this Dharma upon reaching it, and ultimately attain the path of Buddhahood, called unobstructed.

Practicing the bodhisattva path, always diligently practicing, never abandoning or wearying of the roots of goodness, gathering and accumulating meritorious virtues without violating or abandoning them, respecting all and revering good friends, going to Dharma teachers, buddhas, and bodhisattvas, closely consulting and receiving, hearing their sutra teachings, serving and attending to them with immeasurable diligence, traveling to countless lands, embracing and protecting the cycle of birth and death, and liberating infinite kinds of sentient beings.

Practicing the bodhisattva path, the mind always holds the foremost resolve, and always peacefully and completely possesses the mind of true reality, never forgetting worldly and transcendent dharmas, and cultivating contemplation of the four abodes of mindfulness.

Furthermore, observing the external body, the body's activities are impermanent, suffering, empty, and not the activities of the body;
Observing the internal and external body as impermanent, suffering, empty, and not the affairs of the body.
Observing internal feelings, seeing feelings as empty, and cultivating practices exclusively;

Single-mindedly cultivating signlessness, also not violating the bodhisattva mind, accumulating and cultivating the practices of the Great Vehicle without slacking off, the mind returning to the Dharma, this is called the foundations of mindfulness.

They delight in the scriptures and delight in the joy of the Dharma. Because they seek the Dharma, they practice diligently. This Dharma joy has no form or class. Among those obscured by the five hindrances, inverted views, and confusion, they distinguish and explain the five gates of liberation, thereby liberating them!
Among those with afflictions, they distinguish and explain the path factors of the Buddhas of the ten directions, thereby liberating them!
Having practiced this Dharma and ultimately perfected it, one attains the path of the Buddha, and therefore is called the TathÄgata who does not lose the liberation of deliverance.

Because one who is able not to lose liberation is without anger, ultimately without deficiency in the fundamental, pure in the beginning and end, wandering through all destinations, entering the profound and wondrous spiritual wisdom that one attains, which is unobtainable and extremely difficult to bear!

Free from defilement and impurity, without flaws, ultimately pure and adorned, the deeds of tranquil observation with something to say in the mind, inexhaustible and immeasurable, then in the unconditioned without obstruction, practicing the equality of space, well cultivating samÄdhi called the treasury of separation from defilements.
All illuminating all dharmas, understanding dhÄraá¹‡Ä«, the TathÄgata's teaching of the Dharma all understanding the thought of liberation.

To put it briefly, if it is a stingy mind or a generous mind;

An ordinary person's mind or a sage's mind;
A mind heading towards wrong views or a mind heading towards right views;
The mind of the ÅšrÄvaka Vehicle, the mind of the Pratyekabuddha Vehicle, the mind of the Great Vehicle, or the mind that understands the Great Way.

Moreover, knowing the cause of the truth of suffering, this is the truth of accumulation. The cessation of suffering is the truth of the cessation of suffering. Those who aspire to the Way should discern it as it is.
Having already been able to understand the truth of suffering as it is, then know that fundamental purity is without arising, and ultimately without the wisdom of accumulation.

And knowing the truth of suffering as it truly is, there is also nothing to eliminate, and there is nothing to believe that will be completely extinguished. Understanding the path enters everywhere, and is controlled equally like empty space, without self and without craving.

Moreover, that place is originally completely pure. They all understand the origin of these four truths, discern them as they are without creating any realization, and transform sentient beings to eliminate the truth of vows and practice clear realization.

If one expounds the Dharma for the sake of the multitude, by the Dharma that is expounded one attains true gentleness and compliance, and does not become confused or deluded regarding dependent origination. One abandons all heterodox views and enters the middle way to contemplate the Dharma of dependent origination. One understands all dharmas and resolves the conditions of karmic retribution. One is not in one's own land, not in the land of others, not in the land of lifespan, not in the land of life, and also not in the land of sentient beings.

One knows that from ignorance one reaches this practice, knows that from practice one reaches consciousness, knows that from consciousness one reaches name-and-form, knows that name-and-form conditions reach the six sense bases, knows that the six sense bases condition reach contact, knows that contact conditions reach feeling, knows that feeling conditions reach craving, knows that craving conditions reach grasping, knows that grasping conditions reach becoming, knows that becoming conditions reach birth, and knows that birth conditions reach old age, death, wailing, lamentation, suffering, and mental anguish.
Thus, the great mass of suffering is brought about by causes and conditions.

If one fully understands emptiness, then ignorance, formations, consciousness, name-and-form, the six sense bases, contact, feeling, craving, grasping, existence, birth, old age, sickness, death, wailing, sorrow, and the great mass of suffering will all be completely extinguished!
One who contemplates in this way sees that the conditions for ignorance are not the conditions for one's own body, nor are they the conditions for a person, a living being, or a sentient being.
If there is no self, no person, no life, and no sentient being, then this is emptiness.
One who knows emptiness does not conceive of permanence or annihilation, and does not conceive of impermanence, let alone annihilation.
Then, in the past, there was no birth and no arising.
If in the past there was no birth and no arising, then in the three times there is no attachment.
Having no attachment to the three times, there is nothing to attain, and thus everything is naturally nonexistent!

Those who are already non-existent and naturally tranquil will then transcend the path of past and future. Those who are able to transcend the path of past and future have the foremost understanding, and with the foremost understanding, it is called the true and correct.
